raw_text:
De Niro film leads US box office
 
 Film star Robert De Niro has returned to the top of the North American box office with his film Hide and Seek.
 
 The thriller shot straight to the number one spot after taking $22m (£11.7m) at the box office. De Niro recently spent three weeks at the top with comedy Meet The Fockers, which was at number five this week. Oscar hopefuls The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby and Sideways all cashed in on their multiple nominations with stronger ticket sales.
 
 In Hide and Seek, De Niro plays a widower whose daughter has a creepy imaginary friend. Despite lukewarm reviews from critics, the film took more than the expected $18m (£9.5m). "The element of a real actor in a psychological thriller certainly elevated it," said Bruce Snyder, president of domestic distribution at 20th Century Fox. Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby led the Oscar hopefuls with $11.8m (£6.3m), coming in at number three during its first weekend of wide release. The Aviator, a film biography of Howard Hughes that leads the Oscar field with 11 nominations, was at number six for the weekend with $7.5m (£4m). Oscar best-picture nominee Sideways entered the top ten for the first time in its 15th week of release. It came in seventh $6.3 (£3.35m). Last week's top film, Ice Cube's road-trip comedy Are We There Yet?, slipped to second place with $17m (£9m), while Coach Carter fell two places to number four, taking $8m (£4.25m) in its third week. Rounding out the top ten were In Good Company - starring Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson - Racing Stripes and Assault on Precinct 13.
llama3.2:1b: Robert De Niro's film "Hide and Seek" was a box office success, taking $22 million at the US box office, leading to him spending three weeks at number one. De Niro also starred in "Million Dollar Baby", which earned $11.8 million, while Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby" came in third with $11.8 million. Other films that performed well included "The Aviator", "Sideways", and "Assault on Precinct 13".
llama3.2:3b: Robert De Niro's film Hide and Seek leads US box office, taking $22m (£11.7m) at the number one spot. Oscar hopefuls The Aviator, Million Dollar Baby, and Sideways performed well with stronger ticket sales.
gemma2:2b: Robert De Niro's "Hide and Seek" topped the US box office with $22 million, followed by Clint Eastwood's "Million Dollar Baby." Oscar contenders like "The Aviator," "Sideways," and "Million Dollar Baby" also saw strong ticket sales.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A US movie starring Robert De Niro has become the highest-grossing film of all time, taking $22 million in box office revenue over its first weekend after a disappointing performance with "The Aviator". The film features a widower playing a daughter who has an imaginary friend and scores more than expected at the box office. The second-week movie was "Meet The Fockers", coming in fourth with $15 million (£800, 000). "Hide and Seek" also made it to the top five at the box office after receiving lukewarm reviews from critics. Oscar hopefuls are leading a field of films like "The Aviator", "Sideways", "Ice Cube's road-trip comedy", and "Racing Stripes". The movie was nominated for best picture, which led to it taking 10 entries in the box office competition.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Robert De Niro's film Hide and Seek topped North American box office with $22 million, surpassing "Meet the Fockers" at number five after a three-week reign. Oscar hopefuls like "The Aviator," "Million Dollar Baby," and "Sideways" also saw strong performances due to their nominations.
qwen2.5:3b: Robert De Niro's film Hide and Seek took the top spot at US box office, earning $22m (£11.7m), despite lukewarm reviews. The thriller followed Meet the Fockers' success with $18m (£9.5m) in its third week. Oscar hopefuls Million Dollar Baby ($11.8m/$6.3m), The Aviator ($7.5m/$4m), and Sideways ($6.3m/$3.35m) also performed well. Ice Cube's Are We There Yet? dropped to second, while Coach Carter fell from first to fourth. In Good Company, Racing Stripes, and Assault on Precinct 13 rounded out the top ten.

The thriller Hide and Seeke took the number one spot ahead of Oscar hopefuls The Aviator, Million Dolar Baby and Sideways. Hike and Seek, which starred Robert De Niro as a widower with a creepy imaginary friend, has taken more than expected reviews from critics and over $18m in ticket sales. Despite lukewarm reviews, the film took an impressive $18m (£9.5m) during its first weekend of wide release. Clint Eastwood's Million Dollar Baby made it to number three, with Howard Hughes' biography The Aviator in fourth place for the weekend, and a 15th week of relase. Oscar best-pictuere nominee Sideways entered the top ten for the first time, coming in seventh place with $6.3m (£3.35m). Last week's top film, Ice Cube's road-trip comedy Are We There Yet?, slipped two places to second place, taking $17m (£9m) in its third week. tinydolphin:1.1b: Summary: De Niro's film Hide and Seek has topped the US box office charts, surpassing The Aviator (which came in at number two) and Meet the Fockers (which took third place). The thriller also scored impressive numbers at the Academy Awards, with four nominations for Best Picture. Million Dollar Baby, starring Clint Eastwood and Anne Hathaway, maintained its position at number three and brought in $11.8m during its first weekend of wide release. Clint Eastwood's film also performed well in the Oscar race, earning a total of 11 nominations and coming in at sixth place in the running for Best Picture. Meanwhile, the Aviator and Ice Cube's road-trip comedy Are We There Yet?, took seventh and ninth respectively, while Coach Carter slipped two places to number four, earning $8m. In Good Company (starring Dennis Quaid and Scarlett Johansson) rounded out the top ten.
